Materials Genome Institute, Shanghai University Shanghai 200444 China A domain knowledge guided machine learning (ML) strategy is proposed to design and discover catalysts for the simultaneous catalysis of chlorobenzene (CB) and nitrogen oxides (NOx). Symbolic regression (SR) is used to find an analytic formula for the acidity of metallic ions and a few ML regression models are developed for the redox ability in terms of standard reduction potential (SRP) of metallic ions, resulting in the recommendations of bi-functions catalysts. The domain knowledge considers that metallic ions with acidity values in the range of 0.5–1.2 are suitable for both catalytic support and active components, while catalytic active component requires metallic ions with high redox ability (SRP>0.4). Symbolic regression gives an analytic formula of ion acidity and the support vector regression model finds the redox ability from the available features. At last, experimental and characterization results verify catalytic performances of the screened-out catalyst formulas. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Machine learning Acidity Redox ability Chlorobenzene Selective catalytic reduction Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the fast development of green economy in recent years, the whole world has proposed much tight requirement on the emission of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (Cl-VOCs), which are excessive toxicity, high chemical stability, and considerable intractability [1–3]. Generally, waste gas, emitted from combustion processes in power plants [4], cement furnaces [5], iron and steel metallurgical industry [6], and waste incinerators [5,7,8], etc., contains the mixture of Cl-VOCs and another pollutant, nitrogen oxides (NOx). Because both Cl-VOCs and NOx are serious threats to the environment and human beings, their control is a must. Currently, catalytic oxidation and selective catalytic reduction (SCR) are the effective technologies to eliminate or reduce Cl-VOCs and NOx emissions [9,10], respectively. Moreover, chlorobenzene (CB) is a typical representative of Cl-VOCs and widely adopted in most labs [11,12] and hence CB is used hereafter to represent Cl-VOCs. Great efforts have been devoted to the development of bi-functional catalysts for the simultaneously eliminate of CB and NOx [5,8,13]. For example, Li et al. reported that the redox ability and surface acidity of bi-functional catalysts play a key role in improving SCR and CB oxidation [14]. Zang et al. suggested that Fe3+ doped CeNb3/TiO2 generated large number of oxygen vacancies and acid sites, thereby showing excellent performance in NOx reduction and CB oxidation [15]. Doping Al3+ into V2O5/TiO2 catalyst increased the Lewis acid (L-acid) and hence enhanced the adsorption of NH3 and CB [7], while doping Sn4+ into SnMnOx/LDO catalysts improved the SCR and o-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB) catalytic oxidation due to the increase of Brønsted acid (B-acid) [16]. Recently, Lin et al. suggested that improving further oxidation ability and increasing B-acid of catalysts are two approaches for the design and discovery of outstanding bi-functional catalysts, while the acidity and redox properties of catalysts still lack quantitative measures, resulting in a significant degree of arbitrariness in the design direction of catalysts [17]. Obviously, an effective, analytic and quantifiable guidance for catalyst design is urgently needed and worth exploring, which motivates the present study. Artificial intelligence and machine learning (ML) are powerful tools to explore the relationship between micro-structure and macro-property of materials [18,19] and demonstrate a considerable ability in accelerating catalyst development. Symbolic regression (SR) aims to the discovery of analytic formulas, rather than most ML black box models [20]. SR lets domain knowledge suggest basic features and a set of math operators, which operate on the basic features to generate a huge space of potential components of a formula, and hence adopts one of genetic algorithms to search for such formula with experimental data. Weng et al. successfully used SR to guide the design of novel oxide perovskite catalysts with improved oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activities [21]. Their material domain knowledge suggested element electronic parameters, such as the number of d electrons for transition metal ions, electronegativity values and valence state of A and B-site ions in perovskite, and lattice structural parameters, such as ionic radii (r), octahedral factor ( μ ), and tolerance factor (t) as the basic features and their math operator set contained +, -, × , ÷ , √ , only. Accordingly, they generated ∼8640 potential components of a formula. Subsequently, a simple mathematical formula VRHE = ( 1.554 μ t + 1.092 ) was selected by the SR with 1080 experimental data, where VRHE denoted potential versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The formula VRHE = ( 1.554 μ t + 1.092 ) guided the design and synthesis of new oxide perovskite catalysts for OER, resulting in five excellent ones. Remarkably, four of them, Cs0.4La0.6Mn0.25Co0.75O3, Cs0.3La0.7NiO3, SrNi0.75Co0.25O3, and Sr0.25Ba0.75NiO3, exhibit the highest catalytic activities among the oxide perovskite catalysts. The domain knowledge applies the Pauling electronegativity [22] to metallic oxides and suggests the acidity of a metallic ion as [23–25]. (1) S O = V / N O where S O is the acidity or the bonding strength of the metallic ion, V is its valence state, and N O is its coordination number. Although the valence state of a metallic ion is available, it is hard to have the value of its coordination number, because the calculation of coordination number of a metallic ion demands a large amount of data or empirical information. That is why the present work conducts SR in order to find a user-friendly formula of acidity. In this work, the acidity and redox properties of metallic ions are proposed to guide bi-functional (simultaneous catalysis of CB and NOx) catalyst design, and an evaluation method based on atomic parameters is established through machine learning. In this strategy, SR is used to find an analytic formula for the acidity and a few ML regression models are developed for the redox ability, resulting in the recommendation of bi-functions catalysts. Subsequently, the candidate catalysts were confirmed by the experimental results. Six novel bi-functions catalysts are discovered by the domain knowledge guided machine learning strategy. 2 Methodology 2.1 Data and algorithms 2.1.1 Data acquisition Table S2 lists the collected 52 acidity data, including four basic ionic and element features of valence state (V), ionic radius (R), atomic radius (R0), and electronegativity (E0), and the objective of acidity. In addition to acidity, the standard reduction potential (SRP) is another objective to measure the redox properties of ions [26]. A high SRP value of an ion indicates strong oxidation ability of the ion, and vice versa. Table S3 lists collected 87 SRP values for reduction reactions. Features used in the ML of oxidation ability are the same as those listed in Table S2. Each of the two datasets is randomly divided into the training and test subsets with an 8:2 ratio. 2.1.2 Symbolic regression The SR code in the Python library gplearn is used here with the math operator set of +, -, × , ÷ , √ [27], which works on the four basic features and generates 80 initial formula components. The workflow of SR is illustrated in Fig. S1 and the involved hyper-parameters are listed in Table SI-1. The mean absolute error (MAE) and the coefficient of determination (R2) are employed to evaluate the model prediction. The model complexity is represented by the number of operators involved in the formula. The present work selects the final formula with the highest prediction accuracy and the operator number less than 5. The details can be found in Supporting Information. 2.1.3 Regression analysis The regression analysis of SRP is conducted with few ML algorithms, including support vector regression (SVR), random forest regression (RFR), Gaussian process regression (GPR), and extreme gradient boosting decision tree regression (XGBR), and implemented on Python (https://www.python.org/). Table SI-2 lists the tuned values of hyper-parameters used in the ML models. The coefficient of determination (R2) is used to indicate the fitness of the ML model. The details are also provided in Supporting Information. 2.2 Acidity descriptor generation and redox ability evaluation Fig. 1 schematically illustrates the work flow. The SR purpose is to select ionic species with the appropriate acidity level within the range (0.5–1.2), because ionic species with too high acidity values are thermally unstable and too low acidity values are obviously bad. Once ions pass the acidity criterion, they are fed into the ML regression models, which evaluate their redox ability. After that, oxides with metallic cations of both high acidity and high redox ability are used as the active component oxide, whereas oxides with metallic cations of only strong acidity are utilized for forming supports or/and doping oxides. Accordingly, we carry out experiments to prepare the ML suggested catalysts and characterize their performance in simultaneous removal of CB and NOx. The SR gives the formula of acidity = V Ro 0.23 + Eo × R of low complexity (complexity=4) and Fig. 2a shows the prediction excellence of the formula with MAE= 0.026 on the 52-acidity data. Fig. 2b gives a clear linear correlation between the predicted acidity value and actual acidity value (R2(train)= 0.98 and R2(test)= 0.99). The formula indicates that for a given metallic ion, which atom has a certain atomic radius (R0) and electronegativity (E0), the ion will have higher acidity if the ion is in a higher valence state (V) and with a lower ionic radius (R). For ions sharing the same valence state (V), these ions have high acidity if their atoms have smaller atomic radius (R0) and the lower value of electronegativity (E0) * ionic radius (R). The analytic formula is very much user friendly. Fig. 2c shows the coefficient of determination R2 values on the testing set are 0.91 for the GPR model, 0.88 for the XGBR model, 0.92 for the SVR model, and 0.91 for the RFR model, and thus the SVR model performs the best and hereafter is used to predict the SRP of ions. Fig. 2d shows the predicted value from the SVR model versus the actual value for both the testing set and training set, indicating perfect prediction. Subsequently, the metallic oxides with metallic ions of both high redox ability (SRP>0.4) and high acidity are selected for the active components. 2.3 Screening, synthesis and testing of catalysts Table S4 lists the evaluated 91 ions and Fig. 3 shows their acidities and redox properties. The stable acidic ions with an acidity value in the range of 0.5–1.2 are highlighted in blue. The results indicate that ions like Ce4+, Co3+, Mn4+, Mn7+, Ru8+, V5+, Fe6+, and Cr6+ satisfy the criteria of high acidity and redox ability and may serve as the active component in catalysts. Among them, Mn7+, Ru8+, Fe6+, and Cr6+ oxides have high activity and are susceptible to thermal decomposition, rendering them unsuitable for use as catalysts. Alternately, Fe3+, Ti4+, Zr4+, Mn3+, W6+, and Mo6+ possess strong acidity and can be employed as acid additives or supports. Raising the reaction temperature promotes redox ability and improves the catalytic oxidation potential of these ions. Additionally, main group ions such as Al3+, P5+, Sn4+, and Si4+ provide acidic sites and are promising materials for use as carriers and additives (Table S5). The chemical composition of a catalyst is expressed by A a x B b y C c z O o , where A, B, and C denote metallic atoms (ions) and O denotes oxygen atom (ion); a, b, and c stand for the molar fractions of A, B, and C, respectively, with a+b+c= 100 and o is the molar number of oxygen to maintain the charge neutrality of the catalyst molecule; x, y, and z stand for the valence states of A, B, and C, respectively. Accordingly, the acidity and redox capacity of a catalyst in this study are calculated with the method that catalyst acidity is the sum of the product of ion acidity times its molar number of all metallic ions and the redox capacity is the sum of the product of ion SRP (SRP>0.4) times its molar number. The variation in the metallic ions and the change of a, b, and/or c makes the search space of novel catalysts extremally large. The present work with the domain knowledge guided ML has discovered six novel dual-functional catalysts for simultaneously catalysis of CB and NOx, which identifications and compositions are listed in Table S6. In addition, Table S6 also shows the dual-functional catalysts reported in the literature [7,8,15,28–33]. Fig. 4a-b show the CB catalytic oxidation and SCR activities of these six catalysts, respectively. In general, the catalysts display high catalytic oxidation efficiency of CB, with over 80% conversion efficiency. Specifically, V 15 5 Fe 85 3 O 165 and W 1 6 ( M n ( 1 / 3 ) 2 M n ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 29 T i 70 4 O ( 545 / 3 ) exhibit exceptionally excellent CB catalytic oxidation performance (90 +%). All other catalysts exhibit a NOx conversion efficiency higher than 90% at temperatures between 300 and 350 °C. Besides, these catalysts with strong oxidizing and acidic properties also demonstrate low-temperature SCR activity, as illustrated in Fig. S2-a. Although the NH3 peroxidation causes the degradation of high-temperature performance in ( M n ( 1 / 3 ) 2 M n ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 74 F e 26 3 O ( 413 / 3 ) , the introduction of WO3 and MoO3 with strong acidity and low reducibility has overcome this drawback, as observed in the aforementioned catalysts. As an example, the ( M n ( 1 / 3 ) 2 M n ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 74 F e 26 3 O ( 413 / 3 ) catalyst, shown in Fig. S2 -b, exhibits the N2 selectivity was 70 % and 34 % at 300 °C and 350 °C, respectively. However, with the addition of WO3, the N2 selectivity significantly increases to 84% at 300 °C and 78 % at 350 °C. Similarly, the doping of MoO3 resulted in N2 selectivity of 81% at 300 °C and 73% at 350 °C. It is evident that the acidity of the catalysts plays a crucial role in determining the N2 selectivity in the NH3-SCR reaction, and the N2 selectivity is enhanced with the incorporation of highly acidic components such as WO3 or MoO3. Fig. 4c-d shows the simultaneous catalysis of CB and NOx. The presence of CB has generally little impact on the SCR performance, while the CB catalytic oxidation is significantly inhibited by SCR at low temperatures. This inhibitory effect can be reduced by elevating the reaction temperature, such as the performance of V 15 5 Fe 85 3 O 165 catalyst indicated in Fig. S3. In the simultaneous catalysis process, when the temperature increases from 300 ℃ to 350 ℃ and to 400 ℃, the SCR conversion efficiency remains stable around 94%, while the catalytic oxidation efficiency of CB gradually increases from 61% to 76% and 98%. But, catalysts that possess weaker oxidizing properties of active components, such as WO3 and MoO3, still exhibit the inhibited catalytic oxidation behavior (Fig. S4). Previous studies have reported that NH3 competes with CB to adsorb and consume reactive oxygen species [28], thereby inhibiting the catalytic oxidation of CB. The mechanism is revised in strong oxidizing catalysts, to which the presence of CB inhibits NH3 peroxidation and promotes SCR activity [28]. Furthermore, these six catalysts exhibited a high N2 selectivity (80 +%) while effectively removing CB and NOx at 300 °C, as illustrated in Fig. S5. Notably, catalysts V 11 5 Ti 89 4 O 411 / 2 and V 15 5 Fe 85 3 O 165 have an exceptional N2 selectivity exceeding 95%. Therefore, the ideal catalyst should possess enhanced acidity and redox ability, enabling dual-function catalytic activity and ensuring a high N2 selectivity. 3 Experimental section 3.1 Catalyst synthesis Fe 2 O 3 , Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 30 Ti 70 4 O 545 / 3 and Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 74 Fe 26 3 O 413 / 3 were synthesized via a precipitation method using manganous acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(CH3COO)2·4 H2O) and Iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O) as precursors, P25 titanium dioxide as supports, and 10 wt% of NaOH solution as a precipitator. W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 29 Ti 70 4 O 545 / 3 , W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , Mo 1 6 ( Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , V 11 5 Ti 89 4 O 411 / 2 , and V 15 5 Fe 85 3 O 165 were synthesized using a wet impregnation technique that involved active precursor, P25 titanium dioxide or Fe2O3 as supports, and citric acid monohydrate (C6H10O8) as co-solvent. Ce 37 4 Co 1 / 3 2 Co 2 / 3 3 30 Mn 33 4 O 180 was prepared using a redox method in which Ce (III), Co (II), and KMnO4 were used as precursors. The preparation details of the catalyst were given in Supporting Information Section I. Text (Synthesis of catalysts). 3.2 Characterizations The catalysts were characterized using characterized X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), pyridine infrared spectrum (Py-IR) and N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. The detailed steps and settings can be found in the Supporting Information. 3.3 Catalytic performances Catalytic experiments were carried out in a temperature-programmed catalytic system [34], which carried out catalytic oxidization of CB and NH3-SCR by a fixed-bed reactor (14 mm in diameter and 30 mm in length). In each test, 1 g of catalyst was set in the reactor. Inflow gas contained [NOx] = [NO] + [NO2] = [NH3] = 1000 ppm (when used), [CB] = 700 ppm (when used), [O2] = 10%, and the rest was [N2]. The mixture gas flowed at 300 ML/min, i.e., weight hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 18000 ML/(h·g). Residual concentrations of CB and NOx were continuously analyzed by MultiGas™ 6030 FTIR analyzer (MKS Instruments, Inc). NOx, CB conversions and N2 selectivity were calculated by Eqs. (2–4), where subscripts “in” and “out” stand for inflow and outflow, respectively. A catalytic performance of 120 min was used to show catalytic stability. (2) N O x conversion ( % ) = NO x in − NO x out NO x in × 100 % (3) CB conversion ( % ) = CB in − CB out CB in × 100 % (4) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NO x ] out − [ NH 3 ] out ) × 100 % 4 Results and discussion As expected, the domain knowledge guided ML discover the catalyst of V 11 5 Ti 89 4 O 411 / 2 , which is one specific one of V a 5 Ti 100 − a 4 O ( a + 400 ) / 2 catalysts. The V a 5 Ti 100 − a 4 O ( a + 400 ) / 2 catalysts are the state-of-the-art catalysts with exceptional performance in the catalytic oxidation of CB and SCR [35]. The simultaneous catalytic conversion efficiencies of CB and NOx at 350 ℃ of the newly discovered novel catalyst of V 11 5 Ti 89 4 O 411 / 2 are 97% and 99%, respectively, which are correspondingly higher than 20% and 99% of V 4 5 Ti 96 4 O 202 catalyst.32 In addition, the domain knowledge guided ML discovers these catalysts of V 15 5 Fe 85 3 O 165 , W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , Mo 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 29 Ti 70 4 O 545 / 3 , and Ce 37 4 Co 1 / 3 2 Co 2 / 3 3 30 Mn 33 4 O 180 , which have not been systematically studied yet so far. In the present work, each of the six catalysts is characterized repeatedly twice by the pure SCR test, the pure CB catalytic oxidation test, and the simultaneous SCR and CB catalytic oxidation CB test. Fig. 5 illustrates the performance of simultaneous removal of CB and NOx at 300 ℃ of 20 catalysts (14 collected from the literature and 6 discovered from the present work). All the 20 catalysts have the NOx catalytic efficiency larger than 60%, while the CB catalytic efficiency varies from 5% to 88%. The result is consistent with the above statement that achieving high NOx conversion efficiency is relatively easy, whereas it is relatively hard at one-shot to have high CB conversion efficiency as well. The discovered 6 catalysts, however, perform excellently in the simultaneously removal of CB and NOx. Moreover, the present work tested the 6 discovered catalysts under the condition of 700 ppm CB and 1000 ppm NOx, while the 14 collected catalysts were tested in the less CB and NOx concentrations. The acidity and redox ability of catalysts are plotted in Fig. 6, where the acidity ranges from 0.5 to 0.8 and redox ability (SRP) is higher than 0.4. Furthermore, the mean of the two catalytic efficiencies η CB + NO x = 1 2 η CB + η NO x is used to evaluate the catalyst performance of simultaneous removal of CB and NOx and to rank the 20 catalysts. The two collected catalysts of MnO2 and Al 9 3 Ce 91 4 O 391 / 2 (Al-doped CeO2) rank at the top. Dai et al. believed that the excellent performance of the MnO2 stems from the high concentration of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst [29]. Lu et al. asserted that the strong dopant-oxide pairs in Al 9 3 Ce 91 4 O 391 / 2 significantly enhanced the amount of acid sites and promoted the ability of lattice oxygen to act as an oxidizing agent [33]. Nevertheless, MnO2 and Al 9 3 Ce 91 4 O 391 / 2 both have the strong redox ability, higher than 1.0, and both acidities are within the right range. Following the two top catalysts are the four newly discovered catalysts, namely V 15 5 Fe 85 3 O 165 , W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , Mo 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , and Ce 37 4 Co 1 / 3 2 Co 2 / 3 3 30 Mn 33 4 O 180 . In addition, all the 6 catalysts discovered by the domain knowledge-guided machine learning show excellent one-shot CB and NOx conversion efficiency, higher than 60% for CB catalysis and 90% for NOx catalysis under the inlet pollutant concentrations (700 ppm CB + 1000 ppm NOx). The W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , Mo 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 , and Ce 37 4 Co 1 / 3 2 Co 2 / 3 3 30 Mn 33 4 O 180 catalysts achieve the high NOx conversion (95 +%) and high CB conversion (80 +%). The W 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 and Mo 1 6 Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 73 Fe 26 3 O 418 / 3 were improved from the Mn 1 / 3 2 Mn 2 / 3 3 74 Fe 26 3 O 413 / 3 by introducing strong acidity components (WO3 and MoO3), which once again proves the importance of strong acidity in the co-removal reaction. In addition, the catalyst Ce 37 4 Co 1 / 3 2 Co 2 / 3 3 30 Mn 33 4 O 180 , which combines Ce4+, Co2+/Co3+, and Mn4+, also exhibits excellent co-removal efficiency. A series of characterizations were conducted to understand the mechanisms of the newly discovered catalysts. Table S7 lists the characterization results, including the crystal phase, specific surface area, and surface acidity. Figs. S6-S9 show the XRD patterns and N2-adsorption-desorption profiles of the newly discovered catalysts. It is evident that the catalysts primarily comprise of TiO2 or Fe2O3 as the support with significant active components of Mn3O4, CeO2 and Co3O4 in high content and WO3, MoO3, V2O5 and MnO2 in low content. The specific surface area of Fe2O3 based catalysts is ∼50 m2/g, while that of TiO2-based catalysts is ∼40 m2/g. The support components mainly determine the pore size and pore volume, whereas the introduction of active components, such as WO3-Mn3O4 and MoO3-Mn3O4, further raises the specific surface area to ∼80 m2/g. The C e 37 4 ( C o ( 1 / 3 ) 2 C o ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 30 M n 33 4 O 180 , prepared using a redox precipitation method, exhibits a remarkably high specific surface area (173.48 m2/g) and an extremely small pore size (6.49 nm). Abundant micro-mesoscale pores and large specific surface areas significantly enhance the activity. Figs. S10-S113 show the NH3-TPD and Py-IR characterization results of the six catalysts. If a catalyst exhibits the high capacity of NH3 desorption at temperatures above 350 °C, the present work regards it the strong acid catalyst. The strong acid ratio is defined as the ratio of the area of the desorption curve above 350 ℃ to the area of the entire desorption curve. As indicated in Table S7, catalysts composed of active components consisting of ions with acidity > 0.7 exhibit a high value of strong acid ratio. The molar ratio of Mn ions over other metallic ions, which is defined by n Mn ∑ n Me with n Mn and ∑ n Me denoting the molar quantity of Mn and other metallic ions, respectively, is used to represent the Mn ion content. Catalysts with high Mn ion content, such as in fabricated W 1 6 ( M n ( 1 / 3 ) 2 M n ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 73 F e 26 3 O ( 418 / 3 ) with the molar ratio = 0.73, exhibit a high proportion of strong acid, while catalysts with low Mn ion content, such as in fabricated W 1 6 ( M n ( 1 / 3 ) 2 M n ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 29 T i 70 4 O ( 545 / 3 ) , and C e 37 4 ( C o ( 1 / 3 ) 2 C o ( 2 / 3 ) 3 ) 30 M n 33 4 O 180 , have a lower proportion of strong acid. The result is consistent with these reports [36,37]. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the strategy of domain knowledge guided ML, which makes the success of the novel discovery of bi-functional catalysts. The two descriptors of acidity and standard reduction potential are the key and effective descriptors to catch the bi-functional catalysis, while there are more descriptors which deserve deep exploration to fully and analytically catch the catalytic properties. Nevertheless, the domain knowledge guided ML paves the avenue for the fast development of novel catalysts. 5 Conclusions This work proposes a domain knowledge guided ML strategy to accelerate the discovery of bi-functional catalysts for simultaneously removing CB and NOx. The domain knowledge suggests that metallic ions with acidity values in the range of 0.5–1.2 are appropriate for both catalytic support and active components, while catalytic active components require metallic ions with high redox ability (SRP>0.4). With available basic features of metallic ions, the SR finds an analytic formula of acidity and the SVR model delivers the redox ability of SRP. The two descriptors capture the key catalytic behavior of simultaneously removing CB and NOx and thereby can be used to guide the design and fabricate the bi-functional catalysts. The executed preparation experiments, catalytic experiments, and acid characterization experiments exhibit the excellent performance of the newly discovered bi-functional catalysts and confirm the significance of two descriptors in the development of novel bi-functional catalysts. Although more comprehensive and systematic investigations are needed to fully understand the mechanisms of bi-functional catalysis, these results demonstrate that domain knowledge guided machine learning strategy is a powerful tool for the design and discover catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A domain knowledge guided machine learning (ML) strategy is proposed to design and discover catalysts for the simultaneous catalysis of chlorobenzene (CB) and nitrogen oxides (NOx). Symbolic regression (SR) is used to find an analytic formula for the acidity of metallic ions and a few ML regression models are developed for the redox ability in terms of standard reduction potential (SRP) of metallic ions, resulting in the recommendations of bi-functions catalysts. The domain knowledge considers that metallic ions with acidity values in the range of 0.5–1.2 are suitable for both catalytic support and active components, while catalytic active component requires metallic ions with high redox ability (SRP>0.4). Symbolic regression gives an analytic formula of ion acidity and the support vector regression model finds the redox ability from the available features. At last, experimental and characterization results verify catalytic performances of the screened-out catalyst formulas.
coredata.dc:title: The design and discovery of catalysts for simultaneous catalysis of chlorobenzene and nitrogen oxides via domain knowledge guided machine learning
